articles.headline: Drone Strike Killed No. 2 in Al Qaeda, U.S. Officials Say
articles.snippet: Abu Yahya al-Libi, the Qaeda deputy leader who escaped American custody in 2005, was killed in Monday’s drone strike in Pakistan’s tribal belt, American officials said.
articles.abstract: Abu Yahya al-Libi, the Qaeda deputy leader who escaped American custody in 2005, was killed in Monday’s drone strike in Pakistan’s tribal belt, American officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A Central Intelligence Agency drone strike in Pakistan’s tribal belt killed Al Qaeda’s deputy leader, Abu Yahya al-Libi, American officials said on Tuesday, dealing another blow to the group in a lawless area that has long been considered the global headquarters of international terrorism but the importance of which may now be slipping.
articles.byline: By Declan Walsh and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Obama’s Fate May Depend on Europe
articles.snippet: With President Obama’s re-election dependent on the American economy — and Congress blocking stimulus measures at home — decisions made in Europe may well determine his chances.
articles.abstract: With President Obama’s re-election dependent on the American economy — and Congress blocking stimulus measures at home — decisions made in Europe may well determine his chances.
articles.lead_paragraph: The recent downshift in the economy has dealt a powerful blow to President Obama’s chances of re-election in November. But perhaps most worrying for the president is just how little sway he retains over where the economy goes from here.

articles.headline: After Loss, JPMorgan Regulators in Spotlight
articles.snippet: Congress is expected to quiz regulators on Wednesday about their failure to keep an eye on the JPMorgan unit responsible for a trading loss of more than $2 billion.
articles.abstract: Congress is expected to quiz regulators on Wednesday about their failure to keep an eye on the JPMorgan unit responsible for a trading loss of more than $2 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — JPMorgan Chase’s regulators will be in the spotlight here on Wednesday, when they testify before Congress on the bank’s multibillion-dollar trading blunder and its implications for the future of Wall Street regulation.

articles.headline: A Concert Mogul Is Betting on Electronic Dance Music
articles.snippet: Robert F. X. Sillerman made the concert business more corporate and wants to do the same with the latest trend in the music industry.
articles.abstract: Robert F. X. Sillerman made the concert business more corporate and wants to do the same with the latest trend in the music industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: The man who corporatized the concert industry is back, and he wants to dance.

articles.headline: Airtime Adds to a Growing Choice of Video Chat Services
articles.snippet: Airtime, a live video chat service designed by Sean Parker and Shawn Fanning, the founders of Napster, hopes to recreate the spontaneity of the 1990s AOL chat rooms.
articles.abstract: Airtime, a live video chat service designed by Sean Parker and Shawn Fanning, the founders of Napster, hopes to recreate the spontaneity of the 1990s AOL chat rooms.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Americans first started exploring the online world en masse in the early 1990s, many of them headed for AOL’s chat rooms to connect with other curious strangers.

articles.headline: Greece Warns of Going Broke as Tax Proceeds Dry Up
articles.snippet: Officials in Greece said that despite the latest bailout, the government faces a shortfall of 1.7 billion euros because tax revenue and other sources of income are rapidly disappearing.
articles.abstract: Officials in Greece said that despite the latest bailout, the government faces a shortfall of 1.7 billion euros because tax revenue and other sources of income are rapidly disappearing.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — As European leaders grapple with how to preserve their monetary union, Greece is rapidly running out of money.

articles.headline: More Young Americans Out of High School Are Also Out of Work
articles.snippet: A new survey finds that those without a college degree have dismal job prospects and considerable obstacles blocking improvement.
articles.abstract: A new survey finds that those without a college degree have dismal job prospects and considerable obstacles blocking improvement.
articles.lead_paragraph: For this generation of young people, the future looks bleak. Only one in six is working full time. Three out of five live with their parents or other relatives. A large majority — 73 percent — think they need more education to find a successful career, but only half of those say they will definitely enroll in the next few years.
